'9','2014-09-02','Researchers from North Carolina State University are trying to turn a living moth into a remote-controlled robot, or biobot. By attaching tiny electrodes to the moth, they can monitor the electrical signals the moth uses flight to communicate with its muscles. The researchers, also working on a similar project with cockroaches, believe that insect biobots could be used to search through rubble during rescue missions.'

'26','2014-09-05','Wawrinka won 33 points in the opening set but hitting two huge forehands winners, inside-in down the line, in the second game of the set was all that mattered. The Swiss finished the with an ace down the middle in the ad court to take the early advantage.

Nishikori had five break points in the second set and ultimately converted on one when Wawrinka double faulted at 5-6, 30-40, to level the match. Nishikori had only won 55 percent (6 of 11) of his first serve points in the opening set, but locked down to win 91 percent (20 of 22) in the second set.

The third set was one of the best sets the tournament has seen.

Nishikori stole it, 9-7, in the tiebreaker after failing to convert a set point with Wawrinka serving at 2-5, ad out. Nishikori cooked a forehand down the line into the net that he should have taken cross court.

Nishikori played a horrible game at 5-3, missing a tweener off a lob at 15-30 with Wawrinka standing behind his own baseline. It should have been a forehand, but showtime unfortunately took over.

Wawrinka had another break point at 5-5, 30-40, but pushed a wide backhand into the net from very deep behind the baseline. It was one of the big questions of the match: why did Wawrinka play so deep against an opponent he had to attack?

Wawrinka by 5-3 in the tiebreaker and then by 7-6 to serve for the set. But Nishikori stepped up with an insane backhand winner down the line that should only be attempted once every 100 years. Wawrinka missed a backhand return long on the next point and Nishikori had stolen the third set.

The fourth set was an emotional letdown for the players after such a spectacular third, and they motored along to an eventual tiebreaker with only one break-point opportunity for the set. Wawrinka raced to a 4-1 lead in the tiebreaker before closing it out, 7-5, when Nishikori netted a backhand return on set point.

The fifth set was similar to the fourth, and Nishikori finally broke with Wawrinka serving at 4-5, 30-40.

Matches like these come along once in a while. The winner moves on, and you wish the loser could as well.'

'59','2014-09-11','France upset Spain, 65-52, in front of its stunned fans in the quarterfinals of the Basketball World Cup on Wednesday in Madrid. After dominating its first six games and blowing out France by 24 points in the group phase, Spain appeared to be the main candidate to dethrone the United States. But France defended well and rebounded even better. Boris Diaw scored 15 points, and Thomas Heurtel added 13 for France. Pau Gasol had 17 for Spain.

On Friday, France will face Serbia, which trounced Brazil, 84-56. Serbia was led by guard Milos Teodosic, who scored 23 points and had four assists.

The United States will play Lithuania on Thursday in the other semifinal.'

'97','2014-09-18','A ban that was to have gone into effect on Wednesday on a videoconferencing system that allows doctors to prescribe abortion pills to women in rural areas was halted by the Iowa Supreme Court. The stay, announced Tuesday, means that Planned Parenthood of the Heartland can continue using the system until the court makes a final ruling on whether the Iowa Board of Medicine had the authority to adopt the ban last year. The group was set to start following the ban after a district judge ruled last month that the board had the authority to regulate such issues and had met requirements for making new rules. Planned Parenthood appealed. The system allows its doctors in Des Moines or Iowa City to prescribe abortion-inducing pills while meeting with patients in rural areas though a secure Internet video connection.'

'115','2014-09-22','The 9 x 18 proposal is a creative attempt by visionary, public-spirited architects to eliminate barriers to the creation of affordable housing. Those barriers include the scarcity of vacant developable space, outdated zoning ordinances and opposition from community residents.

The proposal seeks to build an array of needed resources on the parking spaces that surround New York City Housing Authority projects in transit-rich areas. As reasonable as that sounds in the abstract, the devil will be in the details.

Housing authority residents have suffered from the withdrawal of so much government support that trust is lacking. A huge community-building effort, combined with real evidence of change in how the authority responds to resident requests, is required before fruitful negotiations over land use can begin. Active, informed community boards could play a useful role in bringing residents and planners together to find common ground.

The writer is chairwoman of the Affordable Housing Committee of the New York City League of Women Voters.'

'127','2014-09-23','Lawyers for Gov. Rick Perry asked Monday that he be allowed to skip his Oct. 13 court appearance because he will be in Europe, and asked that he not be forced to attend subsequent pretrial hearings where no evidence is presented. The motion before State District Judge Bert Richardson said that if Mr. Perry is compelled to appear, the hearing should be delayed until at least until Oct. 20 because of his Oct. 12-19 trip to encourage foreign investment in Texas. An Austin grand jury indicted the governor, a Republican, last month on two felony counts of abuse of power for threatening to veto state funding for a public corruption investigative unit. The governor made the veto after the Democratic district attorney who oversees the unit refused to resign following a drunken-driving conviction, drawing an ethics complaint against Mr. Perry from a left-leaning watchdog group.'

'162','2014-09-28','Emily Anne Dyson, the daughter of Patricia Dyson and Deryl L. Dyson of Huntington Beach, Calif., was married Saturday to Paul Anthony Seary, the son of Phyllis M. Seary and Lawrence A. Seary of Beechhurst, Queens. Pastor Kurt Goble, a nondenominational Christian minister, officiated at the Ponte Winery in Temecula, Calif.

Mrs. Seary, 27, is a financial analyst for the Chaps brand at Ralph Lauren in Manhattan. She graduated from the Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising in Los Angeles.

Her father is a partner in Johnson, Hart & Dyson, an accounting firm in Irvine, Calif. Her mother teaches first grade at the John Muir Fundamental Elementary School in Santa Ana, Calif.

Mr. Seary, 34, is a vice president and a portfolio manager in the asset management branch of Goldman Sachs in Manhattan. He graduated from Binghamton University and is a chartered financial analyst.

His mother retired as the rental coordinator in the Kew Gardens, Queens, office of the Argo Corporation, a real estate management firm in Manhattan. His father, who retired as the director of field news operations at WNBC-TV in Manhattan, is the president of the New York Press Club.'

'163','2014-09-28','Emily Hornor Ma, the daughter of Jill A. Hornor and Yo-Yo Ma of Cambridge, Mass., and John Matthew Mistovich, a son of Linda A. Mistovich and Eli Mistovich Jr. of Londonderry, N.H., were married Saturday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Lenox, Mass. The Rev. Michael Tuck, an Episcopal priest, led the ceremony, with the Rev. Christopher J. Waitekus, a Roman Catholic priest, participating.

The couple graduated from Harvard, he cum laude, and she also received a law degree there.

The bride, 29, will keep her name. She is an associate in the white-collar-crime group at the New York law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

Her father, the cellist, is the artistic director of the Silk Road Ensemble, a collective that mixes traditional and modern music. Her mother is an arts consultant in Cambridge.

The groom, 27, works in New York as a vice president at RBC Capital Markets, the investment banking arm of the Royal Bank of Canada. He advises corporations on risk-management strategies.

His mother is a special-education assistant in the Londonderry Early Education Program, a preschool program at the Moosehill School in Londonderry. His father, a retired civil engineer, was an assistant division engineer for the Northeast Corridor at Amtrak in Boston.'
